item.description:
A father who shook his 3-month-old girl to death and dumped her body in trash-strewn woods¬†near Yankee Stadium was sentenced to seven years in prison on Wednesday ‚Äî as the newborn‚Äôs grieving grandfather recalls thinking of her ‚Äúall the time.‚Äù

Damion Comager, 26, was sentenced by Bronx Supreme Court Justice Audrey Stone on first-degree manslaughter and concealment of a human corpse charges for the May 2023 killing of his infant daughter Genevieve.

On top of the seven years behind bars, Comager will face an additional five years of post-release supervision, District Attorney Darcel Clark¬†announced in a statement.

He pleaded guilty to the charges on Aug. 15, according to authorities.

At some point between May 10 and May 16, 2023, Comager violently shook Genevieve to death because she would not stop crying inside a homeless shelter in Highbridge, where the two lived alongside the infant‚Äôs mother, Ivana Paolozzi, prosecutors detailed.

Comager and Paolozzi then dressed little Genevieve‚Äôs body, put her in a stroller, and dumped her bagged remains in a wooded area on the side of the Major Deegan Expressway, authorities said.

The pair were arrested on May 29, 2023, after Comager reportedly confessed to his dad¬†‚Äî who tipped off cops ‚Äî leading to the search that turned up Genevieve‚Äôs body.

Charges against Paolozzi of tampering with physical evidence, concealment of a human corpse, and second-degree obstructing governmental administration are still pending, the DA‚Äôs office said.

She was previously released with monitoring at her arraignment.

At the time, Paolozzi was considered a ‚Äúsignificant flight risk‚Äù due to her holding a Swiss passport while in the US with an expired visa status.

The charges against her were not considered eligible for bail under the state‚Äôs controversial 2019 criminal justice reforms.¬†

‚ÄúIn a shocking display of cruelty, this defendant took the life of his 3-month-old daughter Genevieve and then showed a lack of humanity by leaving the infant‚Äôs body in a garbage-ridden place. This sentence brings justice for an innocent life taken so soon,‚Äù Clark said in a statement after the sentencing.

Damion‚Äôs father, Donald Comager, told The Post that he is ‚Äúgrateful‚Äù his son still has a chance to get his life together, but still thinks about baby Genevieve ‚Äúall the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt just makes me kind of grateful that he still has a chance to get his life together and come home. Seven years is better than life in prison.‚Äù Donald Comager said, noting he hasn‚Äôt spoken to his son since he went to jail.

‚ÄúI worry about him all the time,‚Äù he said.¬†

The grieving grandfather is holding onto Genevieve‚Äôs remains.

‚ÄúI got her remains with me ‚Ä¶ I think about her all the time.‚Äù

He also expressed frustration that Paolozzi has not yet been officially charged.

‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt she go to prison, too. That‚Äôs crazy that she wasn‚Äôt charged,‚Äù Donald Comager said.

‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt talked to her since my son has been to jail.¬†I don‚Äôt know nothing about her.‚Äù

Damion Comager, of Louisiana, met Paolozzi, who is from Switzerland, while traveling in Europe, Comager‚Äôs parents previously told The Post.

The couple moved to New York in December, three months before welcoming Genevieve into their family, according to Comager‚Äôs parents.

Comager struggled with mental illness and was diagnosed bipolar and schizophrenic as a child, his dad said.

He had several prior arrests in the Pelican State on assault, domestic violence, and criminal impersonation charges dating to 2021, according to NYPD sources.
item.author: Georgett Roberts, Zoe Hussain

item.title: Kathy HochulÂú®ÈïøÂ≤õËé±Âæ∑ÊùØÂºÄÂπïÂºè‰∏äÊÅ∂ÊØíÂòòÂ£∞
item.description:
New York Gov. Kathy Hochul was booed multiple times at the 2025 Ryder Cup on Long Island Wednesday ‚Äì and even a joke from talk show host Carson Daly couldn‚Äôt quell the jeers.

Golf fans attending the opening ceremony ahead of the US‚Äôs matchup against Europe unleashed on the Democratic leader as she walked on stage at the Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale, according to social media footage.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the worst,‚Äù one attendee shouted.

Daly, who brought Hochul out, tried to quiet the crowd by joking she isn‚Äôt NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell, but it didn‚Äôt help much, according to the Athletic.

Hochul then asked the crowd to give an ovation for Team USA that dampened the boos briefly, according to the outlet.

As she left the stage, Daly reportedly quipped, ‚ÄúThat went well.‚Äù

But fans‚Äô ire toward Hochul kept going.

When other speakers, including US Ryder Cup team Capt. Keegan Bradley, gave Hochul shoutouts, the boo birds were quick to follow.

‚ÄúGet outta here Kathy,‚Äù another golf fan screamed.

Upstate New York Rep. Elise Stefanik, who is eyeing a challenge of Hochul next year, reveled in the incumbent‚Äôs time in the rough.

‚ÄúFIRE HOCHUL,‚Äù the Republican tweeted. ‚ÄúSAVE NEW YORK.‚Äù

Hochul‚Äôs office skirted around the unfriendly reception in a statement to The Post.

‚ÄúGovernor Hochul is proud to bring three elite golf tournaments to New York over the next decade,‚Äù a spokesperson said.

‚ÄúThe Governor remains committed to ensuring a world-class experience for the more than 250,000 spectators who will enjoy Bethpage State Park and all the region has to offer in the years ahead.‚Äù

Long Island has become increasingly Republican in recent years.

Additional reporting by Vaughn Golden
item.author: Carl Campanile, David Propper

item.title: Zohran MamdaniÂÜçÊ¨°ÂëºÂêÅÊèêÈ´òÁ®éÊî∂‚ÄîÂ∞ΩÁÆ°‰ªñÂú®Â∑ûÈïøÁöÑÊñ∞ÁõüÂèãHochulÂ∑≤ÂèñÊ∂àËØ•ËÆ°Âàí
item.description:
Mayoral frontrunner Zohran Mamdani continued his crusade to hike taxes on corporations and the uber wealthy ‚Äî putting him on a collision course with his new Albany ally Gov. Kathy Hochul.

‚ÄúThe proposal we put forward would raise $9 billion and we would also raise an additional $1 billion from savings and reforms that can be done at the city level,‚Äù Mamdani said at a rally in The Bronx with health care union workers of 1199SEIU.¬†

The increase in corporate tax, which he said would match surrounding states, and hike in taxes for the top 1 or 2% of New Yorker earners has been a cornerstone of the Queens lawmaker‚Äôs campaign.

The socialist candidate said the revenue would cover the loads of freebies being promised, such as free buses, childcare and city-run groceries.

Mamdani has also claimed he could cut NYPD overtime, which has recently come in at a tune of roughly $1 billion.

The plan puts him at odds with Hochul, who has repeatedly sworn to New Yorkers that the state would not raise taxes.

The governor railed against any new taxes back in June, pulling up a common Republican punchline that upping the cost on the wealthy would send more ‚Äúpeople to Palm Beach.‚Äù

But since Hochul‚Äôs bombshell endorsement last week of Democratic nominee, she has largely dodged how the two will work together despite taxes being a key part of Mamdani‚Äôs mayoralty.

Mamdani holds a massive lead in the polls ahead of the Nov. 4 election in the heavily blue city, in a crowded ballot that also includes Republican Curtis Sliwa and Democrats running as independents, incumbent Mayor Eric Adams and former Gov. Andrew Cuomo.

It also comes as Hochul faces a tough road to hold onto power in Albany in her 2026 re-election bid as she loses support in the suburbs.

Pundits have said the governor hopes to galvanize the downstate vote behind her come next year as she‚Äôs set to square off against Rep. Elise Stefanik.
item.author: Haley Brown, Craig McCarthy

item.title: Âú®ÂüÉÈáåÂÖã¬∑‰∫öÂΩìÊñØÔºà Eric Adams ÔºâÁöÑÊîøÂ∫ú‰∏≠ÔºåÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰ΩçËÄÅÈº†Ê≤ôÁöáÊÇÑÊÇÑÂú∞ÈÄÉÁ¶ª‰∫Ü$ 176,000ÁöÑÊºîÂá∫
item.description:
Hizzoner‚Äôs general in his war on rats waved the white flag.

The city‚Äôs first-ever rat czar Kathleen Corradi, has left her $176,000-a-year job, according to City Hall ‚Äî and it‚Äôs unclear if the position will ever be filled again.

Corradi left on her own accord and will be ‚Äúworking to serve the city in a different capacity,‚Äù according to Mayor Eric Adams‚Äô office.

‚ÄùWhen I appointed Kathy Corradi to this historic, unique job, I knew she‚Äôd have the drive and knowledge to send the rats packing from our city,‚Äù Adams said in a statement. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a daunting, complex task, but she‚Äôs handled it with confidence and creativity.‚Äù

City Hall officials said they were still determining next steps on whether the position would be replaced but spokespeople said that the role will continue in ‚Äúsome capacity‚Äù and that the ‚Äúwork will continue‚Äù for Corradi‚Äôs initiatives.

Adams is coming to the end of his first term this year and though he‚Äôs running as an independent candidate, his re-election chances in November remain slim as he‚Äôs trailing in the polls far behind Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani and other candidates on the crowded ballot.

It‚Äôs unclear if any other candidate would appoint a new rat czar if elected.

Corradi, who‚Äôs departure was first reported by the online news outlet The City, spearheaded a number of new initiatives to target Gotham‚Äôs estimated 3 million rats. Those included contraceptive programs and public engagement ‚Äúrat walks‚Äù across the five boroughs and focusing on ‚Äúrat mitigation zones‚Äù or community board districts with the highest rat sightings.

The city has also overhauled its policies on trash ‚Äì an important food source for the four-legged vermin. Enforcement fines went into effect at the beginning this year for trash containerization at Big Apple properties with up to nine residential units with further rollout for larger buildings happening in 2026.

UFO-like ‚Äúempire bins‚Äù have already started popping up in Harlem as part of a pilot program, angering some locals due to lost parking spaces.

Over the course of her over two-year tenure, the city won a few skirmishes ‚Äì overall rat sightings from 2024 to 2022 dropped 4.13% while sightings in rat mitigation zones largely saw steadier drops, like Crown Heights residents reporting 145 less rodents on their local blocks.

Other rat mitigation zones, like Bronx CB-4 which covers parts of Concourse and Highbridge, have seen increased rat sightings this year. Records from 311 show that at least 663 rats have been spotted this year so far, which is far above 2022‚Äôs total of 546 and 2024‚Äôs high of 482.

Former Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who is running as an independent for mayor, said through spokesperson Rich Azzopardi that the campaign hasn‚Äôt ‚Äúsettled on a rat policy; it‚Äôs not a matter we want to rush or scurry through.

While noting that Cuomo supports efforts like trash containerization, Azzorpardi added that, ‚Äú We‚Äôre chewing over whether to continue with a rat czar, or gnaw through the problem in a different way.‚Äù

Republican mayoral candidate and noted animal advocate Curtis Sliwa said in a statement that while he has offered to be the city‚Äôs rat czar for free, ‚ÄúEric Adams passed, and the rats are running the show.

‚ÄúNow his Rat Czar is fleeing the sinking ship at City Hall while New Yorkers are still dodging burrows, garbage and vermin; under Mayor Sliwa, we‚Äôll fund rat-fighters, not fancy titles.‚Äù

The Mamdani campaign did not respond to a request for comment.
item.author: Matthew Fischetti, Nicole Rosenthal

item.title: 13Â≤ÅÁöÑDunkin 'DonutsÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂ§ñÂ§¥ÈÉ®‰∏≠ÂºπË∫´‰∫°
item.description:
The 13-year-old boy shot in the head by a moped-riding youngster in a brazen Monday morning attack outside a Queens Dunkin‚Äô Donuts has died, police said Wednesday.

Sanjay Samuel, a Martin Van Buren High School student, was struck around 8:20 a.m. when the gunman ‚Äì who sources say was toting a backpack with the ‚ÄúJAWS‚Äù movie logo ‚Äì opened fire in front of the shop at the corner of¬†Linden and Springfield boulevards in Cambria Heights, according to police.

Samuel was rushed to Cohen Children‚Äôs Medical Center, where he was placed on life support and ultimately succumbed to his injuries Wednesday.

Sources have said there was some type of dispute between Samuel and his shooter, but it remains unclear what sparked the clash.

A 14-year-old girl who identified herself only as Mora told The Post the day of the violence that Samuel, who she described as ‚Äúa good kid,‚Äù was her elementary school classmate.

‚ÄúHe was a quiet person from when I knew him, but I think he kind of matured a bit‚Ä¶ He was still a cool person. He would always be friendly with people and play around,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúIt might have been the group he was with ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know if it was his friends, I just knew it was a little situation that happened that was way before. Not today,‚Äù she said, without elaborating.

The youthful-looking suspect ‚Äî who sported an afro and wore a black hoodie, black pants and white sneakers while carrying the distinctive bookbag ‚Äî took off after the shooting, sources said.

No arrests had been made by Wednesday.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: ÂüÉÈáåÂÖã¬∑‰∫öÂΩìÊñØÔºà Eric Adams ÔºâÁöÑÁ´ûÈÄâÊ¥ªÂä®Ê∂àÂ§±Ë°å‰∏∫ËææÂà∞Á¨¨‰∫îÂ§©ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫‰∏öÂÜÖ‰∫∫Â£´ÊÄÄÁñë‰ªñÊòØÂê¶‰ºöÂÆâÈùôÂú∞ÈÄÄÂá∫Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈïøÁ´ûÈÄâ
item.description:
Mayor Swagger has gone cloak-and-dagger.

Eric Adams‚Äô bizarre disappearing act from the campaign trail dragged into its fifth day Wednesday, further fueling rumors he‚Äôs quiet quitting or poised to drop his likely doomed re-election bid.

The radio silence from the floundering incumbent extended to his bare-bones campaign‚Äôs staff and key supporters, who seemed to be in the dark about Adams‚Äô plans ‚Äî with Hizzoner keeping his endgame close to the vest.

One Adams campaign official, asked by The Post about the mayor‚Äôs empty schedule, simply responded with a smiley face emoji.

Adams, while eschewing campaign events, did find time in his role as mayor of the nation‚Äôs largest city to meet Wednesday with Bart De Wever, the prime minister of Belgium, the Eurozone‚Äôs sixth-largest economy.

‚ÄúAn internal poll has him ahead in Brussels right now in the four-way (mayoral) race,‚Äù one source close to the campaign joked.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt care right now. This f‚Äìking campaign has gone so crazy.‚Äù

Adams has adamantly insisted he‚Äôs staying in the race, but his AWOL approach to campaigning may indicate the writing is on the wall with barely a month before November‚Äôs election.

Polls show Adams, a Democrat running as an independent, in an embarrassing fourth place behind frontrunner Democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani, former Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa.

Pooh-bahs concerned about a socialist mayor, from President Trump to big business leaders, have tried to pressure candidates, especially Adams and Sliwa, to drop out to engineer a more winnable two-way race against Mamdani.

‚ÄúI heard it‚Äôs a matter of time and donors are getting mad at him and Cuomo for not doing this more elegantly,‚Äù one Democratic source said.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs doing what he wants to do, I guess,‚Äù another Dem source said.

The mayor‚Äôs dwindling campaign appearances coincided with his backers seemingly giving up on trying to drum up support.

Just one $4,000 contribution flowed into a super PAC supporting Adams this month.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm on another call right now, but if you can try again later, maybe toward the end of the day,‚Äù the lone donor told The Post, declining the chance to boost Adams.

The pro-Adams PAC Empower NYC put out its last video ad and text message blast on Sept. 9, campaign finance records show.

By contrast, PACs supporting Cuomo and Mamdani have put out 23 campaign ads or texts in the weeks since the pro-Adams group‚Äôs last outreach to voters.

But Adams‚Äô low-key, bordering on nonexistent campaign presence hasn‚Äôt completely extended to his mayoral duties and nightlife extracurriculars.

Instead of courting voters Tuesday, Adams apparently took time to grab dinner at the iconic Rao‚Äôs restaurant with ‚ÄúShark Tank‚Äù mogul Kevin O‚ÄôLeary, according to a Tuesday Instagram post.

He also hobnobbed with an Albanian TV host amid the United Nations General Assembly, another Instagram post shows.

Hizzoner also raised eyebrows and inspired mockery Tuesday for a flashy, Star of David-spangled robe he wore to a Rosh Hashanah event in Brooklyn.

‚ÄúBro is dressed like Gandalf the Goy,‚Äù one X user snarked.

‚ÄúHow do ya do, fellow Jews?‚Äù a Reddit poster quipped, referencing a popular meme mocking out-of-touch attempts by outsiders to fit into groups they don‚Äôt understand.

When asked about Adams‚Äô lack of campaign events, spokesman Todd Shapiro said, ‚ÄúThe mayor is busy with his official business and focused on United Nations Week.‚Äù
item.author: Craig McCarthy, Matt Troutman

item.title: Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë∂ÖÂ∏ÇÂèëÁé∞ÁöÑË∂ÖÁ∫ßÁ®ÄÊúâÊ©ôËâ≤ÈæôËôæ‚Äì‰ΩÜËèúÂçï‰∏äÊ≤°ÊúâÂá∫Áé∞Ôºö ‚Äú3000‰∏áÂàÜ‰πã‰∏Ä‚Äù
item.description:
An ultra-rare orange lobster returned to the ocean off the coast of Long Island Wednesday after the crustacean was discovered at an upstate supermarket ‚Äì just a claw-length away from ending up on someone‚Äôs plate.

The ‚Äú1-in-30-million find‚Äù ‚Äî nicknamed Jean-Clawd Van Damme ‚Äî was rescued from a Tops supermarket near Rochester, New York on Sept. 15 by shopper Kyle Brancato, who immediately recognized the animal as something special and snatched him up.

‚ÄúThe Atlantic Ocean is nowhere near Rochester, so he panicked,‚Äù said Humane Long Island executive director John Di Leonardo, who Brancato contacted for rescue advice.

The upstate shopper was able to house Jean-Clawd in a cooler filled with tank water until volunteers drove the crustacean down to Long Island‚Äôs North Shore, where he was ‚Äúrehabbed‚Äù by Di Leonardo before he was released back into the ocean Wednesday morning.

‚ÄúWe gave him a second chance at life,‚Äù Di Leonardo told The Post of the ultra-rare lobster. ‚ÄúWe kill about 100 million lobsters every year in the US, so the fact that he got to survive and he got to make it is a feat in and of itself.‚Äù

The release was done just a day before National Lobster Day on Sept. 25.

‚ÄúI wanted to turn this holiday on its head, as it‚Äôs largely a marketing holiday,‚Äù Di Leonardo said. ‚ÄúMany countries [like Switzerland, Norway and New Zealand] have banned boiling them alive because it‚Äôs incredibly cruel: They feel every moment of it, it takes a long time for them to die.‚Äù

The animal rescuer ‚Äì who reports tossing back eight lobsters to the ocean in the last two years ‚Äì argues the lobsters are ‚Äústarved‚Äù from the time they are caught to their days inside a grocery store tank, which can be up to a month.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so stressful they‚Äôll often fight ‚Äì or self-mutilate or cannibalize one another,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúRubber bands cause them a lot of pain.‚Äù

Di Leonardo said he will often spend about an hour in the water with crustaceans introduced back into the wild, making sure they‚Äôre healthy.

‚ÄúA lot of them have really different personalities,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSome of them will lift their claws and threaten you, others will swim away from you ‚Ä¶ on two occasions they swam closer to us and then swam away.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always a treat.‚Äù

Di Leonardo encouraged ‚Äúany stores that would like to pardon a lobster for the holiday‚Äù to reach out to his organization.

Long Island lobsters have previously been ‚Äúpardoned‚Äù at Northport Fish & Lobster, Stop and Shop‚Äôs Southampton and Syosset locations and ShopRite of Bay Shore.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt care if they‚Äôre blue, brown or orange,‚Äù Di Leonardo added. ‚ÄúThey want to live all the same.‚Äù¬†
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal

item.title: Â∏ñÂ≠êÊëÑÂΩ±Â∏à‰ª•DJÁöÑË∫´‰ªΩÂú®ÈïøÂ≤õ‰∏∫Steve AokiÊãçÊëÑÊúàÂÖâ
item.description:
It‚Äôs a picture perfect gig for this Post photographer.

A paparazzo for the paper who moonlights as a DJ is going from breaking news to breaking out the hits this weekend opening for Steve Aoki on Long Island.

‚ÄúI photographed weddings for 30 years, and in most cases, I would say the DJ stunk,‚Äù Dennis A. Clark said of what sparked his second career as DJ Dennis the Menace.

‚ÄúThe vibe wasn‚Äôt there, the DJ had his head down the whole time, doing nothing.

‚ÄúI wanted to go change that. I dance with people in the crowd and make everybody have fun. DJs forget it‚Äôs our job to make sure people are having fun, not just playing music.‚Äù

Clark‚Äôs up-tempo style is an ideal match for Aoki, whose schtick is throwing cakes into the high-octane crowd.

The dessert and dancing will take place at a free Nassau County concert at Eisenhower Park, where doors open at 5 p.m. on Friday, and Clark will go on at 6:30 p.m.

‚ÄúMy stage name is DJ Dennis the Menace, and I live up to it,‚Äù said Wantagh resident Clark, 59, who prides himself on mixing live and never pre-records his sets.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to give the audience a sugar rush before Aoki takes the stage.‚Äù

Clark has been shooting for the New York Post for more than two decades, documenting tragedies like the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 in Queens ‚Äî while mixing in celebrity pics of big-name stars like Danny DeVito, Shaquille O‚ÄôNeal, Paris Hilton, and Lindsay Lohan.

‚ÄúAs a photojournalist, I‚Äôm always chasing after people ‚Äî but as a DJ, they‚Äôre coming to me,‚Äù he laughed.

Clark branched out to open an entertainment company as a side hustle in 2021, where he received a crash course on modern digital DJ equipment, having only casually spun old-school records on vinyl as a high schooler in the 1980s.

‚ÄúAfter my third lesson in 2021, my instructor said, ‚Äòyou don‚Äôt need me, you‚Äôve got this,‚Äù he boasted.

Quickly, Clark‚Äôs reputation for big energy and fun for all preceded him.

By 2022, swanky Hamptons clubs started calling, while he was also spinning in huge wedding and event venues, such as the overwhelmingly elegant 620 Loft and Garden at Rockefeller Center.

Adrenaline is no issue when it comes time to take the stage, as Clark has previously flown with the Blue Angels, dove with sharks, and was suspended from a helicopter to photograph Trump‚Äôs Mar-A-Lago wedding.

‚ÄúStill, you never get used to it; each rush is different in its own way, but you learn to thrive on it,‚Äù Clark said, adding that this weekend will be the biggest crowd he‚Äôs ever had, as the 2024 show drew 30,000.

‚ÄúIf I ever wanted there to be a snapshot taken of my life, it would be Friday night.‚Äù
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: ‚ÄúÊù•Ëá™Âú∞Áã±ÁöÑÂ¶ìÂ•≥‚ÄùÂú®‚ÄúÂÜ∑ÈÖ∑Êó†ÊÉÖ‚ÄùÁöÑÊä¢Âä´ËÆ°Âàí‰∏≠Áî®Ëä¨Â§™Â∞ºÊùÄÊ≠ª‰∫Ü3ÂêçÁ∫¶Áø∞ÔºöÊõºÂìàÈ°øDA
item.description:
A hooker from hell killed three Johns when she fed them fentanyl to knock them out and rob them ‚Äì leaving one victim dead with his pants at his knees, Manhattan prosecutors charged Wednesday.

Prostitute Tabitha Bundrick, 38, is accused of carrying out the ‚Äúcalculated‚Äù and ‚Äúcallous‚Äù scheme that targeted at least four victims across upper Manhattan, running off with their phones, sneakers, clothes and cash, according to the Manhattan District Attorney‚Äôs Office.

Bundrick was in custody at the time of the new charges and is already facing a federal prison sentence after pleading guilty in August to drug distribution charges tied to the same crime spree. She is now facing three state murder counts and related charges.

‚ÄúI want to be very clear to those who think they can get away with drugging and robbing unsuspecting victims: working with our law enforcement partners, we will uncover and prosecute this conduct,‚Äù¬†Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg said in a statement.

The escort‚Äôs deadly reign began on April 30, 2023 when she convinced Mario Paullan, 42, and his pal to come back to an apartment where they‚Äôd trade cash for sex, Manhattan Assistant District Attorney Dafna Yoran said during her arraignment.

She offered each victim what she claimed was cocaine,¬†Yoran said.

‚ÄúShe was encouraging them, pushing them to take these drugs even though the deceased victim says he‚Äôs never done these drugs before,‚Äù Yoran said. ‚ÄúAnd then she encourages him to do it, to do it again and do it again a third time.‚Äù

Paullan died at the scene, and the pal woke up in an empty apartment next to his friend‚Äôs body, she said.

‚ÄúThat is all the surviving victim remembers ‚Äî snorting one time,‚Äù the prosecutor said. ‚ÄúThe next thing he remembers is he wakes alone in the apartment, but for his friend who is laying there motionless. He can‚Äôt wake him up.‚Äù

Five months later, Bundrick met up with Miguel Navez, 39, and the pair went back to his Washington Heights apartment, where she fed him fentanyl-laced drugs, according to the district attorney‚Äôs office.

Days after that encounter, Navez‚Äôs brother found him dead with his pants around his knees, and many of his personal belongings cleaned out, Yoran said.

The prostitute allegedly followed the same scheme on Feb, 25, 2024, killing Abrihan Fernandez inside his upper Manhattan apartment.

She was caught on surveillance camera going in and out of the building, hauling away several ‚Äúgiant laundry bags,‚Äù including four pairs of sneakers, prosecutors alleged. ¬†

She was arrested on March 5 on initially only robbery charges.

Bundrick‚Äôs lawyer, public defender Eric Burse, claimed his client is ‚Äúnot the cold-hearted individual or calculated killer that the [prosecutors] believe her to be.‚Äù

‚ÄúInstead, she‚Äôs someone who‚Äôs overcome a lot of brokenness, adversity in her life,‚Äù said Burse, who said Bundrick is mentally ill and is a child sexual abuse victim.

Bundrick, dressed in a tan prison suit, was remanded to Rikers Island. She‚Äôs was hit with a 13-year sentence for the federal drug charges.

Bragg called the defendant‚Äôs alleged actions ‚Äúextremely calculated‚Äù and urged other possible surviving victims to come forward.

‚ÄúThis callous behavior allegedly led to the deaths of three people,‚Äù he said.¬†

She faces 25 years to life if convicted on the new indictment.
item.author: Kyle Schnitzer, David Propper

item.title: ÂèçÈ©¨ÂßÜËææÂ∞ºPACËÇ°Á•®ÁÖßÁâáÂ§±Ë¥•ÊúâÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏Ç‚ÄúÈÄâÊ∞ë‚ÄùÁöÑÁÖßÁâáÔºåÂπ∂Ê≤°ÊúâÊÑöÂºÑ‰ªª‰Ωï‰∫∫
item.description:
A prominent super PAC aimed at taking down mayoral frontrunner Zohran Mamdani tried to pass off stock photo models as everyday New Yorkers in a series of ads ‚Äî but the images weren‚Äôt fooling anyone.

New Yorkers for a Better Future‚Äôs photo fail targeted social media users with ads painting the Democratic nominee as nice but not up to the challenges of the job ‚Äî but ironically the supposedly average city slickers had appeared in other paid promotions.

‚ÄúHe sounds nice. But Mamdani has zero experience,‚Äù says a woman in one of the ads identified as Robinette, 55, from the Bronx ‚Äî but the same photo of Robinette is seen on a website providing information to caregivers of dementia patients.

Another ad shows a woman, Ling, 51, from Chinatown, asserting, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a good man with bad ideas. That‚Äôs why I won‚Äôt vote for Mamdani.‚Äù Yet, the same woman is featured on a website in a completely different ad.

The super PAC is backed by Capitol Partners‚Äô Jeffrey Leb and other real-estate bigwigs like Silverstein Properties.

The group has brought in nearly $2 million in donations since October ‚Äî but has failed to move the needle on driving votes away from the Queens socialist who critics have slammed for radical left policy proposals and a longshot pushes to increase the corporate tax and hike taxes on the wealthy.

‚ÄúAre we still supposed to listen to these ‚Äòtitans‚Äô of industries who are fearful of Mamdani killing the city while they can‚Äôt manage to do anything without being a national embarrassment?‚Äù a Democratic operative asked The Post.

A PAC supporting candidate Andrew Cuomo, Fix the City, which has raised over $27 million since the former governor announced his candidacy as made similar missteps.

Shortly before the primary, Mamdani called out the Bill Ackman-backed group for allegedly sending out draft campaign mailers that intentionally darkened and lengthened his beard.

An August report by government watchdog group Citizens Union found that despite $46 million dollars being spent through PACs across seats in the city‚Äôs primary races ‚Äî most of the groups‚Äô preferred candidates did not win their prospective seats.

‚ÄúThey failed. In most competitive races where Super PACs invested heavily in support of
or in opposition to a specific candidate, their preferred candidate lost,‚Äù the report read.

Now with Mamdani leading the polls in November‚Äôs general election by a commanding 20-percentage points ‚Äî it appears some mega-spending groups have been backed into a corner.

‚ÄúAfter months of backroom scheming and millions of dollars in real-estate-backed money, all the billionaires can come up with are stock images and fake quotes,‚Äù said Mamdani spokesperson Dora Pekec,

‚ÄúThe strength of Zohran‚Äôs movement is undeniable and New Yorkers are making it clear they‚Äôre ready for a city they can afford,‚Äù Pekec said.
item.author: Craig McCarthy, Hannah Fierick

item.title: ËÇá‰∫ãÈÄÉÈÄ∏ÁöÑÂè∏Êú∫ÊëßÊØÅ‰∫ÜÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁöÑÊ∏∏ÂÆ¢ÔºåËÆ©‰ªñ‰ª¨ÊâßÁùÄ‰∫éÁîüÊ¥ª
item.description:
A husband and wife visiting the Big Apple from Germany are clinging to life after a hit-and-run driver in a green minivan rammed into them in Midtown Wednesday afternoon, police sources said.

The 50-year-old woman and 55-year-old man from Hamburg were struck around 2:40 p.m. at the corner of Fifth Avenue and East 40th Street, according to the sources.

Both were taken to Bellevue Hospital, where they were listed in critical condition, the sources said.

A green minivan fled the scene, and members of the NYPD‚Äôs Highway District Collision Investigation Squad are investigating, the sources said.
item.author: Joe Marino, Amanda Woods

item.title: ËÅå‰∏öÁΩ™ÁäØË¢´ÊåáÊéßÂ∞Ü‰∏ãÁè≠ÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÊé®Âà∞Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Âú∞ÈìÅËΩ®ÈÅì‰∏äÔºåÊúÄËøëÂú®ÂÖ∂‰ªñË¢≠Âáª‰∫ã‰ª∂ÂêéË¢´Ëß£Èõá
item.description:
The homeless man who allegedly shoved an off-duty NYPD cop onto Manhattan subway tracks late Tuesday is a career criminal who was recently cut loose on supervision after randomly slugging someone else on the rails, cops and prosecutors said.¬†

Aaron Walker, 28 ‚Äì who has 18 prior arrests ‚Äì had only been out of cuffs for two days when cops say he hurled the 24-year-old officer onto the downtown roadbed at the Third Avenue L station in the East Village shortly before 7:30 p.m., sending him to the hospital.

Walker was picked up by police a short time later and now faces a top charge of attempted murder, authorities said.¬†

His arrest came on the heels of a Saturday arrest for a local law violation, after officers spotted him smoking a cigarette on board a train at Bedford Avenue and North 7th Street in Williamsburg, authorities said.

Once he was taken into custody for that offense, police realized he was wanted for another apparently unprovoked assault in transit, cops said.

In that case, he allegedly sat down next to a 22-year-old man on board a C train at Fulton Street and Kingston Avenue the afternoon of Sept. 13 and punched him numerous times in the face and head, police said.

That victim ‚Äì a stranger to Walker ‚Äì was hospitalized in stable condition.¬†

The top charge in that case was third-degree assault ‚Äì a misdemeanor that is not bail-eligible, and he was granted supervised release during his Sunday arraignment, the Brooklyn DA‚Äôs Office said.¬†

He was also charged with third-degree attempted assault and second-degree harassment, according to the criminal complaint.

Walker was also arrested on Sept. 17 for allegedly stealing three clothing items and one home decor item from Target on Greenwich Street near Park Place in Tribeca, according to the court doc.¬†

He was charged with petit larceny and criminal possession of stolen property, and released on his own recognizance during his arraignment, over prosecutors‚Äô request for supervised release, the Manhattan DA‚Äôs Office said.

Walker was previously arrested on Aug. 29 for allegedly snatching up several items ‚Äì including vinyl records ‚Äì from a Barnes & Noble store on East 17th Street near Park Avenue South near Union Square, according to the criminal complaint.¬†

He was charged with third-degree burglary and granted supervised release, as requested by prosecutors.

In a similar case on July 23, Walker allegedly stole eight vinyl records worth about $300 from a Barnes & Noble on Atlantic Avenue near Clinton Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, according to that court doc.¬†

He was arrested in August and also cut loose on supervision because the charges ‚Äî third-degree burglary, attempted assault and harassment ‚Äî were not eligible for bail, prosecutors said.¬†

Both Brooklyn and Manhattan prosecutors say Walker was in violation of a signed trespass notice issued in December of 2022, which revokes his privileges to enter any of the bookstore chain‚Äôs locations.¬†¬†

Walker was awaiting arraignment Wednesday in connection to the assault on the off-duty cop, who sources say was heading home from working the United Nations General Assembly security detail.¬†

The officer was walking on the southbound platform when Walker allegedly punched him in the back of the head, grabbed him by his shirt and hurled him onto the southbound tracks, sources said.¬†

Walker also fell onto the tracks during the scuffle, before the two men managed to hoist themselves back onto the platform and began fighting, the sources added.

The unhinged attacker then jumped onto the northbound tracks, running toward the 14th Street-Union Square station, according to the sources.

The victimized cop then called the 13th Precinct and requested additional units to respond to the scene, the sources said.¬†

The responding officers, joined by their injured brother in blue, drove to the Union Square station, where they found Walker on board an uptown L train.

In addition to the attempted murder rap, Walker was also charged with attempted assault, attempted reckless endangerment, two counts of criminal trespassing, and two counts of disorderly conduct, police said.
item.author: Joe Marino, Amanda Woods

item.title: UnionÂèëËµ∑ÊÅ∂ÊØíÁöÑ$ 100‰∏áÂπøÂëäÊ¥ªÂä®ÔºåÂèçÂØπEric AdamsÊé®Âä®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈ©¨ËΩ¶Á¶Å‰ª§
item.description:
The union representing horse carriage riders has launched a $1 million ad blitz through the November election slamming Mayor Eric Adams and others for attempting to ban the horse carriage industry.

‚ÄúEric Adams stabbed us in the back,‚Äù fumed Transport Workers Union president John Samuelsen.

Samuelsen said Adams‚Äô sudden turn against the carriage industry doesn‚Äôt pass the smell test, especially since First Deputy Mayor Randy Mastro used to represent the leading animal rights, anti-carriage group ‚Äî New Yorkers for Clean, Livable, and Safe Streets, or NYCLASS.

TWU Local 100, which reps the 170 horse carriage riders and other industry workers ‚Äî many of whom are immigrants ‚Äî endorsed Adams‚Äô successful 2021 bid for mayor. Overall, the influential union represents 41,000 mostly city subway and rail workers and bus drivers.

Some of the TWU ads are appearing in The Post.

‚ÄúAmbassador Adams? What a joke. You‚Äôre a disgrace. You‚Äôre not even fit to be an ambassador to Alcatraz,‚Äù said one TWU ad, showing an image of a smiling Adams donning a sash as ‚ÄúAmbassador to Turkey‚Äù ‚Äî a dig at his dealings with Turkish interests, part of a dismissed federal criminal indictment.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre an untrustworthy backstabbing rat.‚Äù

Adams signed an executive order last week to phase out the horse carriage industry, expressing concern about the ‚Äúwelfare of horses‚Äù moving in traffic.

He also urged the City Council to approve a law to ban carriage rides in and around Central Park, a tourist attraction for decades.

The council is now considering Ryder‚Äôs Law ‚Äî named after a horse who collapsed and died ‚Äî which aims to ban the carriages, but it has been stuck in the health committee since last summer.

But Samuelsen, noting the corruption scandals that have engulfed the Adams‚Äô administration, is not buying the mayor‚Äôs sudden interest for the welfare of horses, which he maintains are well cared for.

‚ÄúRandy Mastro has a deep connection to the monied interests that support NYCLASS,‚Äù Samuelsen said.

City Hall said Samuelsen‚Äôs barbs were offensive, but confirmed ‚Äî as NYCLASS did ‚Äî that Mastro previously represented the animal rights group before 2019.

‚ÄúMayor Adams stands with the overwhelming majority of New Yorkers who support banning horse-drawn carriages ‚Äî not with these obscene and baseless claims,‚Äù an Adams spokesperson said.

One poll conducted by animal rights groups claimed 71% of New Yorkers support a horse carriage ban.

‚ÄúThis misinformation being pushed doesn‚Äôt change the facts: these carriages are dangerous for everyday New Yorkers,‚Äù the spokesperson said. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs especially disappointing is that this claim ignores our commitment to supporting carriage drivers through the transition, including identifying new employment opportunities.

‚ÄúThe safety and health risks, to both the public and the horses, are well-documented and cannot be ignored,‚Äù the spokesperson continued.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why we‚Äôre moving forward with real solutions, not distractions.‚Äù

Aside from Adams, the other three major candidates running for mayor in November are also on record supporting a horse carriage ban.

Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani has supported the ban as have Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa ‚Äî who also is running on the ‚ÄúProtect Animals‚Äù ballot line ‚Äî and ex-Gov. Andrew Cuomo, running on the independent ‚ÄúFight and Deliver‚Äù ballot line.

Previous Mayor Bill de Blasio also wanted to phase out horse carriages but opposition in the City Council blocked any action.

Meanwhile, a NYCLASS rep told The Post its sending a cease-and-desist letter to Samuelsen and the head of TWU local 100, John Chiarello, to stop the ‚Äúwild lies and defamation that they‚Äôre constantly putting out on social media, their own website and to the media.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs outrageous that John Samuelsen and TWU are blowing $1 million in workers‚Äô hard-earned dues to attack the mayor for standing up against animal abuse,‚Äù NYCLASS spokesperson Edith Birnkrant said.

‚ÄúWhen is the last time TWU spent $1 million making buses and subways safer for their own members?‚Äù

‚ÄúInstead, they‚Äôre doing the dirty work of a handful of wealthy carriage horse owners‚Äîbosses who misclassify carriage drivers, deny them basic worker rights, and exploit both workers and animals,‚Äù Birnkrant said.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt about protecting working people, it‚Äôs about protecting a cruel, corrupt industry, and transit workers should be furious that their money is being wasted on it.‚Äù

Adams last week said the horse-drawn carriages are relics of old New York that ‚Äúno longer work for our city‚Äù after four carriage horses ran wild in three separate incidents through the park this summer.

‚ÄúWhile horse-drawn carriages have long been an iconic fixture of Central Park, they are increasingly incompatible with the conditions of a modern, heavily-used urban green space,‚Äù the mayor said.
item.author: Carl Campanile, Nicole Rosenthal

item.title: Âî§ÈÜí‰π¶Â∫óÔºåÂê∏ÂºïÁòæÂêõÂ≠êÂà∞Ë±™ÂçéÁöÑLES nabeÁ™ÅÁÑ∂ÂÖ≥Èó≠‚ÄîÂíåÂ∑•‰∫∫‰∫íÁõ∏ÊåáË¥£
item.description:
Woke broke the bookstore.

The radical Lower East Side shop that lured drug addicts to its storefront by offering free clothing, food and Narcan suddenly shut down Tuesday ‚Äî sparking internal warfare and finger pointing.

Without warning, Bluestockings Cooperative announced that it would permanently shut down after more than 26 years, stating that ‚Äúdaily operations are unfortunately no longer sustainable on multiple fronts.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis was our absolute last resort. On top of our crew‚Äôs ongoing struggle against the organized abandonment of New York City and the constant crises, the remaining worker-owner and staff are at the limits of what they can manage in terms of health, disability, and finances,‚Äù a statement posted to Instagram reads.

The Suffolk Street shop blamed the closure on its failure as a worker-owned cooperative to ‚Äúcome to consensus around the guiding principles and practices Bluestockings should embody‚Äù ‚Äî adding that an inability to align on political and business operations directly led to the setbacks the business faced over the last two years.

‚ÄúOf course, $12,000 a month in rent, thousands in utilities, and racist, classist violence from ‚Äòneighbors‚Äô certainly didn‚Äôt make our work any easier,‚Äù the statement continued.

Bluestockings came under intense outrage from its posh Lower East Side neighborhood, which transformed into a ‚Äúzombie apocalypse‚Äù of strung-out junkies shooting up in broad daylight who were drawn to the bookstore‚Äôs free and indiscriminate services.

The self-described ‚Äúradically inclusive‚Äù shop was a state-recognized Opiate Overdose Prevention Program and offered¬†‚Äúharm reduction services‚Äù¬†like Narcan, drug-testing strips and a used needle-drop off bin ‚Äî which neighbors alleged enabled the junkies.

In recent years, Bluestockings plunged into around $100,000 in debt to its publishers and book distributors, according to reports.

When The Post visited Wednesday, there were no signs posted indicating its closure. A worker, who was seen taping a ‚ÄúUPS please knock‚Äù sign, declined to comment when approached by a reporter, directing all inquiries toward the bookstore‚Äôs social media statement.

Neighbors, however, celebrated the closure and expressed hope that its termination would finally usher out the five regulars who have turned Suffolk Street into a drug den.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be a plus,‚Äù said Marie, 68, who has lived on the block for her entire life.

‚ÄúI heard they were giving out free needles, which is a good thing and a bad thing because everyone knew where to go, but I guess no one was overdosing from a bad needle ‚Ä¶ You see the [drug] exchanges in front of your face.‚Äù

The retired meter maid admitted that the issue has lessened in recent years, but that the street ‚Äî which houses a pre-school ‚Äî fills up with homeless addicts at night. Police pass through during the day more frequently, she added.

While the decision to shutter the shop might have stifled outrage from neighbors, it ignited a new battle between the employees.

Numerous ‚Äúworker-owners‚Äù of the cooperative flooded the comments section of the Bluestocking‚Äôs closing announcement to claim they had not been consulted before they were fired from their gigs, a move they described as ‚Äúviolent‚Äù and racially-charged.

‚ÄúMy collective of in-store workers, all melanated POC, did not make this decision. the white folks on the lease who are former worker owners made this decision without consulting any of us. hold the white folks attempting to act like this was a collective process accountable. this is false and white violence,‚Äù one employee by the name of Dheivanai¬†claimed.

Fellow ‚Äúworker-owner‚Äù Jay Gandhi, who helped run day-to-day operations, told Gothamist they and other staffers were not told about the closure ahead of time and were booted from the store‚Äôs digital accounts without warning.

‚ÄúThis was not a consensus,‚Äù Gandhi said. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre a cooperative and if you‚Äôre worker-owned, the people who were actually working had not contributed to this decision.‚Äù

Gandhi claims they and other workers were in the midst of transferring ownership from the ‚Äúlegal owners‚Äù and were not told closure was on the table.

Co-owner Raquel Espasande did not immediately respond to The Post‚Äôs request for comment, but told Gothamist that the transition was delayed beyond feasibility because the employees were concerned about inheriting Bluestocking‚Äôs six-figure debt.

While the brick-and-mortar shop has shut its doors, Bluestockings said it would continue to operate through 2025 to fulfill book orders. Memberships will officially turn off Dec. 15.

A GoFundMe originally kickstarted to keep the shop alive will remain active through the remainder of the year, with the $65,000 funds raised so far being put toward settling debts and compensating its crew.
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.title: ÂÆ∂Â∫≠ÊåëÊàòICEÁöÑÂÅáÂÆöÊ≠ªÂõ†ÔºåÊè≠Á§∫‰∫ÜÂú®ÈïøÂ≤õÁõëÁã±‰∏≠Ê≠ª‰∫°ÁöÑÊ¥™ÈÉΩÊãâÊñØÁà∂‰∫≤
item.description:
Federal immigration officials confirmed the identity of a migrant who died in custody inside a Nassau County jail last week and revealed a preliminary cause of death as official probes continue.

Honduras citizen Santos Banegas Reyes, 42, ‚Äî who had been previously deported three times‚Äì appeared to have died from ‚Äúliver failure complicated by alcoholism,‚Äù Immigration and Customs Enforcement said Tuesday.

The official cause of death is still under investigation.

The Honduran father and construction worker was arrested Sept. 18 by federal immigration agents just hours before he was found ‚Äúnot breathing‚Äù in his cell, according to ICE and Oscar Michelen, the attorney representing Reyes‚Äô family with the Long Island Hispanic Bar Association.¬†

Reyes had previously entered the US illegally at least four times from 2004 to 2019, and ICE claimed the detainee previously admitted to a history of alcohol abuse.

But the detainee‚Äôs family pushed back on ICE‚Äôs findings of the cause of death and claimed relatives were only notified that he died by a ‚Äúsource‚Äù and not by federal authorities.

Michelen also claimed that Reyes had no-known health issues leading up to his death, and said his family denies that he was a heavy drinker or an alcoholic ‚Äî which Reyes‚Äô sister called ‚Äúabsurd.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a remarkable coincidence, isn‚Äôt it,‚Äù Michelen told The Post. ‚ÄúThe very same day that he gets snatched away by ICE, a seemingly healthy man just so happens to succumb to chronic liver failure.‚Äù

Reyes‚Äô sister, who asked not to be named for fear of reprisals, said that her brother appeared ‚Äúnormal and healthy‚Äù the day before his arrest at his construction job.¬†

The family is now pursuing an independent autopsy, according to Michelen.

County Sheriff Anthony Larocco said its own ongoing investigation ‚Äúwill be thorough and transparent to determine the cause of death.‚Äù

‚ÄúNassau County takes seriously its obligation to treat every prisoner humanely,‚Äù Larocco said in a statement.

The state attorney general‚Äôs office is also investigating as is protocol with any in-custody death.

The feds also stressed that all detainees in custody ‚Äúreceive medical, dental and mental health screenings and 24-hour emergency care at each detention facility.‚Äù

The death comes after Nassau entered a partnership with ICE that set aside 50 cells at the East Meadow jail to hold detainees nabbed by ICE in New York City and Long Island.

Under the deal, migrants can be held in the jail for up to 72 hours before ICE either deports them or ships them off to a long-term detention facility, with the feds reimbursing the county $195 per detainee, per night.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÊÆãÁñæ‰∫∫‰∏≠ÂøÉÁöÑÂè∏Êú∫Â§öÊ¨°Âú®Èù¢ÂåÖËΩ¶‰∏≠ÂØπÊÆãÁñæÂ¶áÂ•≥ËøõË°åÊÄß‰æµÁäØÔºöË≠¶ÂØü
item.description:
A sicko van driver for the Nassau County Association for the Help of Retarded Children repeatedly sexually assaulted a developmentally disabled woman behind a local Home Depot, police said.

Steven Harrison, 62, of Roosevelt, allegedly drove his AHRC van behind a Jericho outlet of the home improvement retailer on multiple occasions between March 2022 and Sept. 12, then sexually molested the woman before returning to work, Nassau County police said.

The woman, who was 24 when the alleged assaults began, finally reported them on Thursday, and relatives reported it to police, cops said.

‚ÄúAfter conducting a thorough investigation, defendant Harrison was placed under arrest without incident on Sept. 23 at the AHRC located at 189 Wheatley Road in Brookville,‚Äù the department said.

Harrison was charged with third-degree rape, endangering the welfare of of an incompetent physically disabled person and second-degree sexual assault, police said.

Records show he was arraigned on the charges Wednesday and ordered held on $250,0000 cash bail or a bond of up to $2 million pending a return to Nassau County court on Friday.

Harrison pleaded not guilty to the charges.
item.author: Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: Ê≥ïÂÆòË≠¶ÂëäÂè∏Ê≥ïÈÉ®È´òÂ±Ç‰∏çË¶ÅÂÜçË∞àËÆ∫Luigi Mangione Ôºö ‚ÄúÁõ¥Êé•ËøùËßÑ‚Äù
item.description:
Justice Department officials may be jeopardizing Luigi Mangione‚Äôs federal case by continuing to discuss the accused health insurance CEO assassin in public, a judge warned Wednesday.

Social media posts from two high-ranking DOJ staffers ‚Äúappeared to be in direct violation‚Äù of rules barring publicity that could taint the alleged killer‚Äôs jury pool, Manhattan federal judge Margaret Garrett wrote.

The judge warned that future breaches could lead to DOJ brass being fined or the court taking other measures ‚Äúspecific to the prosecution of this matter.‚Äù

Mangione, 27, has pleaded not guilty to federal and state charges of murdering UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson in cold blood outside the insurance giant‚Äôs annual investor conference in Manhattan. The federal government says it is seeking the death penalty.

Wednesday‚Äôs ruling mentions a DOJ spokesman‚Äôs Sept. 19 X post referencing a clip of President Trump saying on Fox News that Mangione ‚Äúshot someone in the back as clear as you‚Äôre looking at me.‚Äù

‚ÄúPOTUS is absolutely right,‚Äù the spokesperson, Chad Gilmartin, said in the since-deleted post.

Gilmartin‚Äôs statement was reposted the next morning by Brian Nieves, the chief of staff to Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche, the ruling says.

Both statements appeared to breach court rules limiting public statements by DOJ officials, Garnett wrote Wednesday. The judge has also signed an order directing that US Attorney General Pam Bondi be made aware that the rule applies to her as well.

Mangione‚Äôs lawyers have argued that recent White House statements baselessly trying to link the accused killer‚Äôs case to other ‚Äúleft-wing‚Äù violence are also threatening his right to a fair trial.

White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt referred to Mangione as a ‚Äúleft-wing assassin‚Äù in a Monday press briefing.

An official White House press release sent out later that day announcing that the left-wing group Antifa has been dubbed a ‚Äúdomestic terrorist organization‚Äù accused ‚Äúleftists‚Äù of cheering on Mangione as part of a list of what it claimed was ‚ÄúRadical Left violence that has permeated the nation in recent years.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Government has indelibly prejudiced Mr. Mangione by baselessly linking him to
unrelated violent events, and left-wing extremist groups, despite there being no connection or
affiliation,‚Äù Mangione‚Äôs lawyers wrote to the court in a late Tuesday letter.

Justice Department officials did not immediately respond Wednesday to a request for comment. The feds have until next Friday to respond to the judge in court papers.

Mangione is due back in court for the federal case on Dec. 5. No trial date has been set.
item.author: Ben Kochman

item.title: Zohran MamdaniÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊúÄÊñ∞Â∏ÇÈïøÊ∞ëÊÑèË∞ÉÊü•‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰∏ªÂØºÂú∞‰Ωç‰∏∫Á´û‰∫âÂØπÊâãÂ∏¶Êù•‰∫ÜÊõ¥Â§öÂùèÊ∂àÊÅØ
item.description:
Democratic mayoral nominee Zohran Mamdani holds a dominant 20-point lead in the race for New York City Hall ‚Äî bolstered by majority support from black, Latino and Asian voters, according to a new poll released Tuesday.

Mamdani leads independent candidate and former Gov. Andrew Cuomo 45%-25% among likely voters as Republican nominee Curtis Sliwa trails with 9% and incumbent Mayor Eric Adams with 8%, the Suffolk University ‚ÄúCityView‚Äù poll found.

But in even more bad news as his rivals cling to hopes of an upset victory, the poll shows Mamdani building support among black and Hispanic voters since his huge victory in the June Democratic Party primary over Cuomo and a slew of other candidates.

Mamdani now leads Cuomo better than 2-to-1 among both minority voters, according to the survey.

Some 53% of black voters support Mamdani compared to 21% for Cuomo, 10% for Adams and 2% for Sliwa, the poll found.

Likewise, 52% of Hispanics back Mamdani, compared with 22% for Cuomo, 8% for Sliwa and 7% for Adams, with the rest undecided or supporting other minor party candidates, according to the poll.

And 58% of Asian voters polled support Mamdani, compared with 20% for Cuomo, 9% for Sliwa and 4% for Adams.

White voters are more split but Mamdani is still ahead with 38% backing compared with 30% for Cuomo, 13% for Sliwa and 9% for Adams and the rest backing other minor candidates or undecided.

Both Cuomo and Adams are running on independent ballot lines, with Adams having skipped the Democratic primary as he faced the fallout from federal corruption charges that were eventually dropped by the Trump administration.

Three other candidates on the ballot include Conservative Party nominee Irene Estrada and independent candidates Jim Walden and Joseph Hernandez.

The results mirror other polls conducted in recent weeks, showing Mamdani with a comfortable double-digit lead.

One notable difference is that other polls had Sliwa getting more support.

For example, the Marist University Institute for Public Opinion survey released a week ago had 17% of voters backing the Republican candidate.

Respondents said the top issues in the mayor‚Äôs race are affordability (21%), crime (20%), economy/jobs (14%), housing (9%), local response to Trump initiatives (8%), racism/justice/equality (7%), and schools/education (6%).

‚ÄúThis poll shows that the issues New Yorkers really care about in this election are affordability, crime, and the economy,‚Äù said David Paleologos, director of the Suffolk University Political Research Center.

The Suffolk CityView survey conducted live phone interviews with 500 likely general election voters from Sept. 16 to 18. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 4.4 percentage points.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: ÊñØÁßëÁâπ¬∑Ë¥ùÊ£ÆÁâπÔºà Scott Bessent ÔºâË≠¶ÂëäËØ¥ÔºåËÅîÈÇ¶Ë∞ÉÊü•Â±Ä‰∏ç‰ºöÂú®‰ΩêËµ´ÂÖ∞¬∑È©¨ÂßÜËææÂ∞ºÔºà Zohran Mamdani ÔºâÁöÑÈ¢ÜÂØº‰∏ãÊãØÊïëÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏Ç
item.description:
The Trump administration will not bail out New York City in any financial crisis if Democratic mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani follows through with his plans, Treasury Secretary Scott¬†Bessent¬†said Wednesday.

‚ÄúI guarantee you ‚Äî and there are not a lot of things in life that are sure ‚Äî that New York City will be coming to the federal government for a bailout if the Mamdani plans are implemented,‚Äù¬†Bessent¬†said in an interview with Fox Business Network.

Asked if he would give the city a bailout under those circumstances,¬†Bessent¬†said, ‚ÄúIt will be the same thing that Gerald Ford said: ‚ÄòDrop dead.'‚Äù

While former President Ford never actually said those words, a New York tabloid headline used the phrase to capture the moment in 1975 when the Republican president refused to bail out New York as it was on the verge of bankruptcy.

Mamdani‚Äôs office did not immediately return a request for comment on¬†Bessent‚Äôs remarks.

Bessent¬†called Mamdani the socialist prot√©g√© of his social media sparring partner, Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren, who spoke out this week against any¬†potential bailout¬†for Argentina‚Äôs government by the Trump administration.

The Treasury secretary did not specify which plans of Mamdani he thought could lead to financial trouble.

Mamdani won his party‚Äôs nomination in a June 24 primary with 56% of the vote and is now a leading candidate in the November election.

His¬†proposals¬†include rent freezes, free city buses, city-owned grocery stores and free childcare, paid for by raising corporate taxes and imposing an extra 2% tax on New Yorkers earning more than $1 million a year.

Bessent¬†was interviewed on Fox‚Äôs ‚ÄúMornings with Maria.‚Äù
item.author: Reuters

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂÆ∂ÊÅêÊÄñ‰π¶Â∫ó„ÄäÊâ≠Êõ≤ÁöÑËÑäÊü±„ÄãÔºà The Twisted Spine ÔºâÂºÄ‰∏öÔºåÂêëÁé∞‰ª£ÁªèÂÖ∏ÂÖúÂîÆ„ÄäÂºóÂÖ∞ËÇØÊñØÂù¶„ÄãÔºà Frankenstein Ôºâ Ôºö ‚ÄúÊ≤°ÊúâÂÖ∂‰ªñÁ±ª‰ººÁöÑ‰π¶‰∫Ü‚Äù
item.description:
New Yorkers just might find something scarier than a rent increase inside a new offbeat storefront.

The Twisted Spine, the Big Apple‚Äôs first horror-focused bookstore, opened in Brooklyn this month, hawking upwards of 1,500 books from ‚ÄúDracula‚Äù to ‚ÄúFrankenstein‚Äù to ‚ÄúThe Haunting of Hill House‚Äù ‚Äì and serving as a spooky place to hang out and have a drink, co-owner Jason Mellow told The Post.¬†

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been difficult to keep everything in stock,‚Äù he admitted as a new 750-book shipment was wheeled into the dimly-lit gothic enclave in Williamsburg Tuesday morning.

‚ÄúWe had a line down the block for six hours, and people were waiting for up to two hours to get in,‚Äù co-owner Lauren Komer said of the store‚Äôs Sept. 6 grand opening.¬†

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only been more intense since then.‚Äù

Mellow, 37, and Komer, 31, ‚Äúbusiness and life partners‚Äù who live in Manhattan‚Äôs Two Bridges neighborhood, began hawking horror books last year after Komer ‚Äì a scientist at the National Institute on Aging ‚Äî sunk her teeth into bone-chilling audiobooks at work.

‚ÄúIt was around the time I was like, ‚ÄòNew York has got to have a horror bookstore, I can pick up a book,‚Äô‚Äù she said, ‚Äúand I was just really shocked that one didn‚Äôt exist already.¬†

‚ÄúYou go to most bookstores, and there‚Äôs one shelf ‚Äì combining mystery, suspense, horror and crime,‚Äù Mellow added. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing else like this.‚Äù

The pair began peddling paperbacks as a pop-up bookstore last September and, despite a five-year plan to launch a brick-and-mortar, were fast-tracked to finding a permanent home thanks to skyrocketing demand among readers and publishers alike.

‚ÄúHorror really celebrates being different and not part of the traditional status quo,‚Äù Komer said of the store‚Äôs dedicated fan base, which raised $40,000 via Kickstarter within months. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre some of the most empathetic and kind people: horror is about being in touch with your own morality.‚Äù

The dark literature haven has since welcomed both horror novices and experts, with books organized into subcategories like Horror 101, comedy and slashers to folk horror and even ‚Äúsplatterpunk‚Äù ‚Äì reserved for the bloodiest, ‚Äúmost extreme horror,‚Äù Mellow said.

‚ÄúWe have a book for everyone,‚Äù Komer added, ‚Äúand a wide variety for all different levels‚Äù of fear fans.

Despite some of the more blood-curdling tales on the shelves, Komer argues the horror ‚Äústays between the pages,‚Äù and the store opts for a cozy, mysterious ‚Äústudy‚Äù feel ‚Äì complete with a fireplace and seating aplenty ‚Äì instead of a ‚ÄúHalloween store when things are popping out at you.‚Äù

The ambiance was chosen to accommodate both the hordes of 20- and 30-something horror fans as well as families and stroller moms who bring their tots to the childrens‚Äô corner, the couple said. The bookstore is even set to host an upcoming children‚Äôs ‚ÄúScary Story Time‚Äù in partnership with the Brooklyn Public Library.

The shop also features an in-house cafe complete with year-round Eternal Pumpkin Spice lattes and themed baked goods, as well as a beer and wine bar at night.

‚ÄúWe wanted to cover all our bases: NYC rent is the real horror,‚Äù Komer laughed, noting the cafe combo is also expected to bolster community at the shop.

‚ÄúWe found that, after COVID, it‚Äôs hard to find a place where you can just relax and read a book and have a coffee at any time of day,‚Äù Mellow added, calling the shop a crucial ‚Äúthird space,‚Äù which is a place to spend time other than work or home.¬†

‚ÄúNYC suffers from a lack of third spaces where people can come together,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄùWe realized pretty quickly that the community aspect was something that people were really searching for.‚Äù

Other events are set to feature international bestselling authors ‚Äì such as Jeong Yu-Jeong, ‚Äúconsidered to be the Stephen King of Korea‚Äù ‚Äì as well as mystery movie nights and ‚Äúsilent‚Äù book clubs.

Fans have flocked to the store in such record numbers that the owners had to move an upcoming panel event of authors to a brewery that could accommodate nearly 200 bookworms who RSVP‚Äôd in just a few hours.¬†

‚ÄúI think that people have undervalued the horror literary community,‚Äù Komer said, noting the genre‚Äôs fanbase is expected to continue to explode in popularity as, ‚Äúin times of political unrest horror, always comes to the forefront.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a way of building resilience to real-life horror.‚Äù
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal

item.description:
The mother of a 13-year-old boy who was left on life support after he was shot in the head outside of a Dunkin‚Äô Donuts in Queens is still praying for a miracle that the teenager will recover.

Sanjay Samuel, a student at Martin Van Buren High School, is ‚Äúbrain dead‚Äù after he was shot outside the coffee shop in Cambria Heights while walking to school on Monday morning, according to his mother, Vilene Griffith.

‚ÄúMiracles do happen, and I‚Äôm trusting God for Sanjay to get up,‚Äù she told CBS New York of her hoops-playing son who dreamed of becoming a firefighter.

‚ÄúNothing is going on. He‚Äôs not breathing on his own. He‚Äôs not doing nothing,‚Äù she said.

Witnesses told The Post that the youthful-looking gunman pulled up to the restaurant on a scooter and got into a short fight with Samuel before he took out a gun and shot him.¬†

The suspect, who had an afro and was carrying a distinctive ‚ÄúJAWS‚Äù bookbag, then ran off, police sources said.

Sanjay was rushed to Cohen Children‚Äôs Medical Center for treatment of his life-threatening gunshot wound. The teen‚Äôs father told the New York Daily News that the bullet is still lodged in the back of his son‚Äôs head.

‚ÄúWe asked them if they could do the surgery to remove the bullet,‚Äù Theophilus Samuel said. ‚ÄúThey said, ‚ÄòNo, that could make it worse.‚Äô‚Äù

The motive for the shooting remained under investigation ‚Äî but a 14-year-old classmate said she believes the typically ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù student may have recently fallen in with the wrong crowd.

‚ÄúIt might have been the group he was with ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know if it was his friends, I just knew it was a little situation that happened that was way before. Not today,‚Äù the teenager told The Post, without divulging further.

No arrests have been made and police have not identified the shooter, whom Sanjay‚Äôs father blasted as a ‚Äúcoward.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow can you live with this? At the moment, you‚Äôre probably hyped. But as time goes by, you have to think ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄòI took another person‚Äôs life,'‚Äù Samuel said.

Griffith wanted to ask the suspect why he shot her son ‚Äî a basketball player who wanted to be a firefighter when he grew up.

Sanjay had just graduated from middle school earlier this year.

‚ÄúI lost my son, and your mom lost you, also,‚Äù she said.
item.author: Patrick Reilly

item.description:
An off-duty cop was pushed onto the subway tracks at a Manhattan L train station Tuesday evening and his alleged shover is now facing attempted murder charges, according to the NYPD and sources.

The 24-year-old victim was shoved onto the track bed by a homeless man at the Third Avenue L station in the East Village shortly before 7:30 p.m., police said.

The man who was thrown off the platform was an off-duty cop, according to sources. He suffered pain in his head and body, the NYPD said.

He was allegedly pushed by Aaron Walker, 28, who also fell onto the tracks during the scuffle, sources said.

The two managed to hoist themselves back onto the platform and began fighting, sources added.

Walker, whose last known address was a Harlem homeless shelter, was arrested at Union Square Station after hopping on an uptown train, according to the sources.

The off-duty officer was taken to Bellevue Hospital in stable condition, according to cops and sources.

Walker was booked on a slew of charges, including attempted murder, attempted assault, attempted reckless endangerment, two counts of criminal trespassing, and two counts of disorderly conduct, police said.
item.author: Larry Celona, Zoe Hussain

item.description:
Fowl play?

A pair of dead chickens were found on the Upper West Side for the second time in four months ‚Äî suggesting a secret religious ritual is at play in the ritzy nabe, according to experts.

The two lifeless golden-feathered birds were discovered Tuesday morning, laying head-to-claw along the median on Broadway and West 91st Street, West Side Rag reported.

The jarring discovery marked the third time in the just over a year that a pair of nearly identical chickens were laid out within a three-block stretch in the area.

Two apparently slaughtered fowl were found on the median at Broadway and West 89th Street just in front of Broadway Malls on May 24.

Those chickens seemed purposefully placed on the curved part at the end of the median which faces into the intersection of the two streets.

Animal activists believe the birds are part of a ‚Äúroutine‚Äù dark ritual sacrifice.

‚ÄúThe similar dates these animals were found underscores the likelihood that they are connected to a routine sacrifice and unlikely to stop without law enforcement intervention,‚Äù John Di Leonardo, executive director of Humane Long Island, told The Post.

‚ÄúWhile animal sacrifice is often¬†associated with Santeria or voodoo, we‚Äôve rescued animals from sacrifices by even Judeo-Christian and Hindu practitioners, like the use of chickens as Kaporos in some Hasidic communities, the killing of cattle during Eid, and the slaughter of pigs and chickens in Shakti ceremonies surrounding Jamaica Bay,‚Äù Di Leonardo said.

These birds likely originated from one of the 80 live slaughter markets that operate in the Big Apple, with many testing positive for deadly disease, according to the activist.

‚ÄúMore than two dozen live slaughter markets in New York City have tested positive for avian influenza this year as well,‚Äù Di Leonardo said.

‚ÄúIt is illegal for live slaughter markets to sell live birds to the public, however, we know live slaughter markets regularly violate public health codes by selling live birds to those who slaughter them in the streets, often for cruel and inhumane animal sacrifice,‚Äù he added.

The poultry pattern traces back to June 25, 2024, when the first pair of deceased cluckers were discovered on the median at West 92nd Street and Broadway, according to the Rag.
item.author: Shane Galvin

item.title: Curtis SliwaË¶ÅÊ±ÇABCÊèê‰æõ‰∏éZohran MamdaniÁõ∏ÂêåÁöÑ‚ÄúÂ∏ÇÊîøÂéÖ‚ÄùÊ¥ªÂä®Áõ∏ÂêåÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥
item.description:
Republican mayoral Curtis Sliwa demanded equal time after his Democratic opponent backed out of a TV ‚Äútown hall‚Äù in a supposed ‚Äúpolitical statement‚Äù over the suspension of comedian Jimmy Kimmel.

Frontrunner Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic nominee, had dropped out of the supposed town hall in protest over the parent company‚Äôs decision to suspend comedian Jimmy Kimmel‚Äôs late night talk show over comments the host made after the assassination of conservative political activist Charlie Kirk.

Sliwa, founder of the vigilante group the Guardian Angels, wrote a scathing letter Tuesday demanding he get the same offer of a town hall as Mamdani‚Äôs campaign said they were ready to reschedule now that ‚ÄúJimmy Kimmel Live!‚Äù has been reinstated.

‚ÄúBecause that coverage is not exempt as bona fide news coverage or reporting, it triggers your obligation to provide me with equal time on the same terms,‚Äù Sliwa said in the letter sent Tuesday to Robert Iger, CEO of The Walt Disney Company and Maril√∫ G√°lvez, president & GM of WABC-TV.

‚ÄúThat means an equivalent opportunity to appear before a comparable audience, under similar conditions of format, duration,‚Äù he added, citing the federal Communications Act of 1934 and the Federal Communication Commission‚Äôs equal time rules.

‚ÄúAs a major party candidate, my qualification for equal time under FCC rules is beyond question. ‚Äú

Sliwa‚Äôs campaign said ABC offered a ‚Äúsitdown‚Äù interview with news anchor Bill Ritter, rather than the town hall format.

‚ÄúThis is what they offered us. Nothing else. And in October [the final weeks before the election],‚Äù said Sliwa rep Rob Cole.

The letter comes a day after Mamdani announced he was skipping his WABC-TV event in protest of Kimmel‚Äôs suspension over comments that tied Kirk‚Äôs assassination to the ‚ÄúMAGA gang,‚Äù who he accused of trying to ‚Äúscore political points‚Äù from the tragedy.

‚ÄúWhether you watch Jimmy Kimmel or not, today‚Äôs decision is a victory for free speech. We‚Äôve reached out to WABC to reschedule the town hall,‚Äù Mamdani said in a statement Monday after it was revealed Kimmel would be back on the national airwaves.

No makeup date has been set for Mamdani‚Äôs town hall, which had purportedly been set for Thursday.

Sliwa asked ABC to disclose the terms and conditions of the appearance provided to Mamdani and ‚Äúextend equivalent promotion and publicity to ensure fairness.‚Äù.

But ABC-TV told the Post later Tuesday there must have been a ‚Äúmix up‚Äù in communications, and that it is not doing town hall sessions with Mamdani or any of the mayoral candidates.

The station offered each campaign an opportunity to come on ‚ÄúUp Close with Bill Ritter‚Äù to answer viewer questions.

Sliwa‚Äôs campaign accepted Tuesday morning, according to WABC-TV.

Cole, Sliwa‚Äôs adviser, said nothing has been confirmed.

Independent candidate Andrew Cuomo‚Äôs campaign said the station informed the former governor that the town hall format was scrapped in favor of studio interviews.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.description:
A New York judge found ‚Äúcredible evidence‚Äù that Oregon Sen. Ron Wyden‚Äôs kids terrorized their mom‚Äôs personal assistant with ‚Äúabhorrent‚Äù homophobic slurs ‚Äì including ‚Äúlittle zest bunny‚Äù ‚Äì before his suicide, documents show.

Wyden‚Äôs wife and the kids‚Äô mom, Nancy Bass Wyden ‚Äî who owns the Big Apple‚Äôs famed Strand Bookstore ‚Äî largely didn‚Äôt object to the accusations her former assistant, Brandon O‚ÄôBrien, raised during their fight over unemployment benefits, noted the administrative-law judge in her Feb. 28 labor decision favoring O‚ÄôBrien.

O‚ÄôBrien, 35, ended up committing suicide in May, allegedly driven to taking his own life after working for Bass Wyden for two years, according to a wrongful-death suit filed by the worker‚Äôs widowed husband, Thomas Maltezos,¬†against her real-estate company, citing the alleged abuse.

Months earlier, when O‚ÄôBrien had attempted to collect unemployment checks after he resigned from Bass Real Estate LLC in Sept. 2024, Bass Wyden fought him on it, arguing he shouldn‚Äôt receive government assistance because he only left the job when he knew he was about to be fired for theft, court papers show.

But¬†administrative law Judge Lorraine Ferrigno ultimately sided with O‚ÄôBrien.

The lawyers for Maltezos say in their lawsuit that the ruling ‚Äúaffirmed‚Äù O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs hostile workplace allegations.

The administrative judge wrote that two of the Wydens‚Äô three kids ‚Äî a then-11-year-old daughter and 15-year-old son ‚Äî texted O‚ÄôBrien messages calling him ‚Äúzesty,‚Äù which can be a homophobic slur.

The texts included such missives as ‚Äúactual zest kitten‚Äù and ‚Äúcan you please order me food my little zest bunny.‚Äù

The teen son also referred to O‚ÄôBrien as a ‚Äúf‚Äì‚Äù or ‚Äúf‚Äî-t‚Äù ‚Äî instances that at times were witnessed by Bass Wyden, who ‚Äústrongly admonished‚Äù her son, according to the judge.

Such accusations have since been mirrored in O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs widower‚Äôs lawsuit.

When O‚ÄôBrien first started working for Bass Wyden, he complained to her that her daughter behaved and spoke sexually and inappropriately around him, and while the mom didn‚Äôt remember the gripe, she recalled the child‚Äôs male au pair leveling a similar complaint, the law judge‚Äôs findings state.

As the harassment dragged on, O‚ÄôBrien finally received one more ‚Äúhomophobic‚Äù message from the son that led him to quit Sept. 30, 2024, according to court docs.

‚ÄúThe credible evidence establishes that [O‚ÄôBrien] voluntarily separated from his employment after he received a homophobic text message from the teenage son of his boss after experiencing prior incidents with the children and nothing changed,‚Äù the ruling states.

The judge wrote that while Bass Wyden couldn‚Äôt recall some of O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs allegations, ‚Äúthere does not seem to be much disagreement that the employer‚Äôs children, more specifically her son, harassed [O‚ÄôBrien].

‚ÄúAdditionally, there seems to not be a dispute that the employer found her son‚Äôs homophobic statements abhorrent and chastised him for them,‚Äù the judge wrote.

Bass Wyden attempted to counter that O‚ÄôBrien only quit because he realized he was going to be fired.

She claimed that the night before he resigned, she discovered he stole from the company, including through credit-card fraud, the judge wrote.

A police report filed by Bass Wyden accused O‚ÄôBrien of stealing about $650,000, but he was never arrested or charged, authorities said.

O‚ÄôBrien died May 26, closing the case.

But the law judge wrote that no ‚Äútestimony or evidence‚Äù shows O‚ÄôBrien was aware that he was about to be fired.

The lawsuit filed by O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs widower¬†claims Bass Wyden spread false rumors about O‚ÄôBrien in a bid to keep him jobless, leaving him distraught.

An e-mailed Post request for comment from Bass Wyden‚Äôs representative and legal team about the labor decision was not returned.

A spokesperson for Bass Real Estate previously called Maletzos‚Äôs lawsuit ‚Äúbaseless‚Äù and ‚Äúdeeply misguided.‚Äù

The company‚Äôs legal team has filed a motion to toss the case.

‚ÄúO‚ÄôBrien was employed as a trusted personal assistant, with a range of responsibilities,‚Äù the rep said.

‚ÄúHis misuse of that trust, and his misrepresentation of the events that took place while in that position, further reveal the depth of his moral corruption and manipulation.‚Äù
item.author: David Propper, Peter Senzamici
